pullrequest.title: Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

content.raw:
@cbillington I’ll be merging this in a few days unless you have any objections, and then tagging a new release of lyse so that we can we can reference it in supplementary material for Shaun's vortex paper.

I added an additional bit of code today so that the user code can be notified of when the analysis script has finished running \(so that it can enable things like buttons that may have been disabled explicitly once the `delay_event` was sent \(to prevent user interaction with custom behaviour when lyse isn’t still waiting for the results to be returned\)
content.html:
@cbillington I’ll be merging this in a few days unless you have any objections, and then tagging a new release of lyse so that we can we can reference it in supplementary material for Shaun's vortex paper.

I added an additional bit of code today so that the user code can be notified of when the analysis script has finished running (so that it can enable things like buttons that may have been disabled explicitly once the delay_event was sent (to prevent user interaction with custom behaviour when lyse isn’t still waiting for the results to be returned)

pullrequest.title: Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

content.raw:
This is fine, although I'm not familiar with how it's being used I'm happy to take your word for it.

On matters of style though, I'd rather not merge commented-out code such as `__init__.py`, line 453 onward and `analysis_subprocess.py` line 129.

I'd also rather avoid the long lines. Could you raise the errors by doing something like (example from work-in-progress DAQmx code):

```python
    msg = """Cannot add analog input to device with no parent pseudoclock.
        Even if there is no buffered output, a pseudoclock is still required
        to trigger the start of acquisition. Please specify a parent_device
        and clock_terminal for device %s"""
    raise ValueError(dedent(msg) % self.name)
```
where `dedent()` is `labscript_utils.dedent()` (and thus depend on labscript_utils 2.8.0)?

This also avoids having the string literal in the exception line itself, which avoids having it print twice when the exception is raised.

I'm limiting lines to 88 characters in all new code I write in accordance with the style automated by [this project, 'black'](https://github.com/ambv/black), which looks like it'll become a sort of standard, so if you're wondering how long is too long, it'd be good to aim for 88 chars (particularly with the strings), though I don't care about 100% compliance (and I don't want to touch existing code for the sake of not making diff noise). Conforming to line length is annoying for strings though, hence why I made the `dedent()` function.
content.html:
This is fine, although I'm not familiar with how it's being used I'm happy to take your word for it.

On matters of style though, I'd rather not merge commented-out code such as __init__.py, line 453 onward and analysis_subprocess.py line 129.

I'd also rather avoid the long lines. Could you raise the errors by doing something like (example from work-in-progress DAQmx code):

    msg = """Cannot add analog input to device with no parent pseudoclock.
        Even if there is no buffered output, a pseudoclock is still required
        to trigger the start of acquisition. Please specify a parent_device
        and clock_terminal for device %s"""
    raise ValueError(dedent(msg) % self.name)

where dedent() is labscript_utils.dedent() (and thus depend on labscript_utils 2.8.0)?

This also avoids having the string literal in the exception line itself, which avoids having it print twice when the exception is raised.

I'm limiting lines to 88 characters in all new code I write in accordance with the style automated by this project, 'black', which looks like it'll become a sort of standard, so if you're wondering how long is too long, it'd be good to aim for 88 chars (particularly with the strings), though I don't care about 100% compliance (and I don't want to touch existing code for the sake of not making diff noise). Conforming to line length is annoying for strings though, hence why I made the dedent() function.

pullrequest.title: Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

content.raw:
Thanks for the feedback, I’ve fixed the things you’ve raised!

In further testing I’ve fixed a bunch of other things to do with how we manage figures, in order to bring the behaviour more in line with how you would expect it to behave when used from a terminal. A description of everything I’ve changed in in the last commit message \(there is also some more in the one before that if you haven’t seen it…can’t remember how much Bitbucket includes in email notifications\). You might want to look over it to make sure it doesn’t break any of your original intentions.

I’ll be merging Monday or Tuesday I think unless Shaun needs it merged sooner.
content.html:
Thanks for the feedback, I’ve fixed the things you’ve raised!

In further testing I’ve fixed a bunch of other things to do with how we manage figures, in order to bring the behaviour more in line with how you would expect it to behave when used from a terminal. A description of everything I’ve changed in in the last commit message (there is also some more in the one before that if you haven’t seen it…can’t remember how much Bitbucket includes in email notifications). You might want to look over it to make sure it doesn’t break any of your original intentions.

I’ll be merging Monday or Tuesday I think unless Shaun needs it merged sooner.

pullrequest.title: Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

content.raw: Pretty much. You need to make a few minor changes \(I’ve changed the call signature of `Plot.analysis_complete()` and you should avoid using `clf()`\). I emailed you about them :slight_smile: but let me know if you find something I’ve missed.
content.html: Pretty much. You need to make a few minor changes (I’ve changed the call signature of Plot.analysis_complete() and you should avoid using clf()). I emailed you about them but let me know if you find something I’ve missed.

pullrequest.title: Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

content.raw:
@cbillington I’ve updated this to include a compatible fix along the lines of pull request #47. It fixes most cases, but there was one case which I couldn’t resolve so I have it printing a warning instead.

The case I couldn’t fix was when your plotting script switches from:

    figure("asd")
    plot(x,y)
    figure(2)
    plot(y,x)

to

    plot(x,y)
    figure(1)
    plot(y,x)

Re-running the script for a second time after the change does resolve it though, which the warning tells you to do \(or to just always explicitly call figure\(\)
content.html:
@cbillington I’ve updated this to include a compatible fix along the lines of pull request #47. It fixes most cases, but there was one case which I couldn’t resolve so I have it printing a warning instead.

The case I couldn’t fix was when your plotting script switches from:

figure("asd")
plot(x,y)
figure(2)
plot(y,x)

to

plot(x,y)
figure(1)
plot(y,x)

Re-running the script for a second time after the change does resolve it though, which the warning tells you to do (or to just always explicitly call figure()

pullrequest.title: Added the ability for analysis scripts to register a custom Plot class

content.raw:
Also, the code for the fix has changed so that the figure is stored only if it was actually produced and exists. This stops crashed code from causing a hidden, empty figure from being created which was then dictating the figure size for future runs of the script \(unless you closed the plot window explicity\), which meant that figures sizes in code were not always respected even on the first successful run.

We need to do something more comprehensive about figure sizes \(preferably add a button to lock \(reset on next run\) figure sizes based no the specifications in the code. This is really easy to do \(the `self.update_window_size()` method is already there\), the main sticking point is finding an appropriate icon :stuck_out_tongue:
content.html:
Also, the code for the fix has changed so that the figure is stored only if it was actually produced and exists. This stops crashed code from causing a hidden, empty figure from being created which was then dictating the figure size for future runs of the script (unless you closed the plot window explicity), which meant that figures sizes in code were not always respected even on the first successful run.

We need to do something more comprehensive about figure sizes (preferably add a button to lock (reset on next run) figure sizes based no the specifications in the code. This is really easy to do (the self.update_window_size() method is already there), the main sticking point is finding an appropriate icon
